one_paragraph_summary: During this admission, a middle-aged woman with advanced AIDS on HAART, ESRD on thrice-weekly hemodialysis, prior V1 zoster with post-herpetic neuralgia, atrial fibrillation, and chronic pruritic rash presented from dialysis with worsening right-sided headache and facial pain, new right facial blistering lesions, diffuse pruritus, dizziness, and mild shortness of breath. Initial evaluation showed chronic macrocytic anemia, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, ESRD-range creatinine and BUN with hyperphosphatemia and intermittent hyperkalemia, but stable baseline low blood pressure and no fever. CT chest showed no PCP and only a small nonspecific right lower lobe ground-glass opacity; CT head and later MRI brain were normal. Dermatology performed punch biopsies of the left arm and right face, which demonstrated eosinophilic hypersensitivity/folliculitis with negative HSV/VZV stains and only coagulase-negative staph on culture, leading to discontinuation of acyclovir and treatment with hydroxyzine and topical mupirocin. A fluoroscopic-guided lumbar puncture yielded normal CSF with negative cryptococcal antigen and cultures, ruling out CNS infection as a cause of headache. She continued M/W/F hemodialysis with transient intradialytic hypotension and improved post-dialysis chemistries; sevelamer was increased and cinacalcet continued. Her HAART regimen (abacavir, atazanavir, ritonavir, emtricitabine) and opportunistic infection prophylaxis (TMP-SMX and azithromycin) were maintained. Atrial fibrillation remained paroxysmal and was managed with aspirin alone. By discharge she was hemodynamically stable at baseline, ambulatory, with improved facial lesions, pruritus, and headache, and was discharged home with services, on her chronic dialysis schedule and updated medications, with follow-up arranged for HIV care and suture removal.

problem_list.problem: Right facial rash and pain in the setting of prior V1 zoster
problem_list.status_at_discharge: Presented with worsening right facial pain and new ulcerative lesions on the right cheek and nasolabial fold, on a background of prior V1 zoster with post-herpetic neuralgia and right eye visual loss. Initial concern was for zoster reactivation, and she received systemic and topical acyclovir. Dermatology biopsies of the left arm and right face showed ulcer with neutrophilic crust and superficial perivascular lymphocytic infiltrate with eosinophils, consistent with hypersensitivity reaction/eosinophilic dermatitis with follicular accentuation; HSV and VZV immunostains were negative, and tissue culture grew only coagulase-negative staphylococcus. DFA and viral cultures from skin scrapings were negative for HSV and VZV. Acyclovir was discontinued after ID and Dermatology review, and she was treated with hydroxyzine for pruritus and mupirocin cream twice daily to the facial lesions. By discharge, the facial ulcerations and pustules were greatly improved, with residual but decreased pain.

problem_list.problem: Headache with photophobia in advanced HIV
problem_list.status_at_discharge: She had chronic headaches that had increased in frequency and severity over several weeks, sometimes associated with photophobia but without nausea, vomiting, or neck stiffness. CT head and non-contrast MRI brain showed no infarct, hemorrhage, mass, or abnormal parenchymal signal. A fluoroscopic-guided lumbar puncture yielded clear CSF with 2 WBC/µL, normal protein and glucose, negative cryptococcal antigen, and negative bacterial, fungal, viral, and AFB cultures, effectively ruling out CNS infection. Headaches were managed symptomatically with oxycodone and later acetaminophen–caffeine–butalbital, with moderate improvement. At discharge she continued to have chronic headaches but at a reduced intensity, with plans for outpatient management.

problem_list.problem: Eosinophilic folliculitis / eosinophilic dermatitis with diffuse pruritic rash
problem_list.status_at_discharge: She had a chronic, intensely pruritic rash with hyperpigmented papules and excoriations on the extremities and trunk, with peripheral eosinophilia on admission. Skin biopsies from the left arm and right face showed ulcer and neutrophilic scale crust with superficial perivascular lymphocytic infiltrate and eosinophils, consistent with hypersensitivity reaction with follicular accentuation, and special stains were negative for HSV, VZV, fungi, and bacteria. This was interpreted as eosinophilic dermatitis/folliculitis, likely related to HIV and possibly drug reaction. She was treated with hydroxyzine for pruritus and topical mupirocin to areas of ulceration; her chronic prurigo lesions were healing by discharge, and itching was significantly improved.

problem_list.problem: End-stage renal disease on hemodialysis with electrolyte abnormalities
problem_list.status_at_discharge: She has ESRD from HIV nephropathy and is anuric on chronic hemodialysis. During this admission she continued thrice-weekly hemodialysis (M/W/F). Pre-dialysis labs showed elevated creatinine (up to ~9.2 mg/dL), BUN (up to 72 mg/dL), hyperphosphatemia, and intermittent hyperkalemia (potassium up to 7.1 mEq/L), which improved post-dialysis (creatinine ~5.8–5.9 mg/dL, BUN in the 17–40 mg/dL range, potassium in the mid-4s). She experienced transient intradialytic hypotension that responded to small saline boluses. Her sevelamer dose was increased, and cinacalcet was continued; she also received doxercalciferol and epoetin with dialysis. At discharge she remained dialysis-dependent but hemodynamically stable, with plans to continue her outpatient dialysis schedule and renal medications.

She has a history of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation and was on aspirin at baseline. During this admission she had at least one brief episode of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response that self-terminated; she remained hemodynamically stable and largely asymptomatic. Rate-control agents were not continued long term, and systemic anticoagulation was not initiated, given her low stroke risk and concerns about bleeding and adherence. She was maintained on aspirin 325 mg daily. At discharge she was in sinus rhythm and clinically stable.

problem_list.problem: Advanced HIV/AIDS on HAART with opportunistic infection prophylaxis
problem_list.status_at_discharge: She has advanced AIDS with a recent CD4 count in the low teens and high viral load prior to restarting HAART. Two weeks before admission she had restarted a regimen of abacavir 600 mg daily, atazanavir 300 mg daily, ritonavir 100 mg daily, and emtricitabine 200 mg twice weekly, which was continued throughout hospitalization. She also received Pneumocystis prophylaxis with TMP-SMX DS three times weekly and MAC prophylaxis with azithromycin 1200 mg weekly. CSF HIV viral load was sent as part of the LP workup. At discharge she remained clinically stable on HAART and prophylaxis, with outpatient HIV follow-up arranged.

Throughout the admission she had leukopenia (WBC ~2.5–3.6 K/uL), macrocytic anemia (hemoglobin ~10.1–12.2 g/dL, MCV 103–105 fL), and thrombocytopenia (platelets ~102–130 K/uL). RDW was mildly elevated. Coagulation parameters (PT, INR, PTT) were normal, and there were no bleeding events or transfusions. The cytopenias were attributed to HIV-related bone marrow suppression and chronic disease. At discharge her counts remained low but stable, and she was clinically well.

key_tests_and_results.test: Initial laboratory evaluation (CBC, BMP, coagulation, LFTs, lactate)
key_tests_and_results.result: On arrival, labs showed leukopenia (WBC 3.3 K/uL), macrocytosis (MCV 103 fL, MCH 33.9 pg), mild anemia (Hgb 12.2 g/dL), thrombocytopenia (platelets 130 K/uL), elevated RDW, creatinine 6.1 mg/dL, BUN 42 mg/dL, potassium 5.7 mEq/L, sodium 142 mEq/L, bicarbonate 22 mEq/L, anion gap 24, normal INR/PT/PTT, normal transaminases and bilirubin, and mildly elevated lactate at 2.1 mmol/L. Eosinophils were markedly elevated at 18.7%.

CT chest showed no signs suggestive of PCP, several small subpleural granulomas, and a 2 cm subpleural ground-glass opacity in the right lower lobe that could be infectious or due to aspiration. There were no pleural effusions and only mild chronic airway wall thickening.

Noncontrast CT head demonstrated no evidence of acute infarct, hemorrhage, edema, mass, or mass effect. There were dense calcifications along the falx and cerebellar tentorium and basal ganglia, likely related to underlying ESRD. Overall, no acute intracranial process was identified.

key_tests_and_results.test: Fluoroscopic-guided lumbar puncture and CSF analysis
key_tests_and_results.result: Fluoroscopic-guided LP at L3–4 obtained 18 mL of clear CSF. CSF studies showed WBC 2/µL, RBC 0/µL, 0% neutrophils, 84% lymphocytes, 16% monocytes, protein 30 mg/dL, glucose 43 mg/dL, LDH 12 IU/L. Cryptococcal antigen was negative, Gram stain showed no organisms, and bacterial, fungal, viral, and AFB cultures showed no growth. Overall, there was no evidence of meningitis or other CNS infection.

Non-contrast MRI of the brain showed no infarct, hemorrhage, mass, hydrocephalus, or abnormal FLAIR signal to suggest a parenchymal process. There was mild pachymeningeal thickening likely post-procedural and mild sinus and mastoid mucosal thickening, but no intracranial pathology explaining the headaches.

key_tests_and_results.test: Skin biopsies of left arm and right face
key_tests_and_results.result: Punch biopsies from the left arm and right face showed ulcer and neutrophilic scale crust with dyskeratosis and superficial perivascular lymphocytic infiltrate with eosinophilia, consistent with hypersensitivity reaction status post excoriation, with follicular accentuation on the facial specimen. HSV and VZV immunostains were negative, and PAS-D and Gram stains did not reveal microorganisms. Tissue culture grew only coagulase-negative staphylococcus. Findings were interpreted as eosinophilic dermatitis/folliculitis, likely drug-related, rather than zoster.

key_tests_and_results.test: Serial chemistry and hematology during hospitalization
key_tests_and_results.result: Over the course of admission, serial labs showed persistent macrocytosis (MCV 103–105 fL), leukopenia (WBC 2.5–3.6 K/uL), thrombocytopenia (platelets 102–130 K/uL), and hemoglobin 10.1–12.2 g/dL. Renal indices fluctuated with dialysis, with pre-dialysis creatinine up to 9.2 mg/dL and BUN 72 mg/dL, improving post-dialysis to creatinine ~5.8–5.9 mg/dL and BUN 17–40 mg/dL; potassium ranged from 4.3 to 7.1 mEq/L, with highest values treated with kayexalate and dialysis. Phosphate remained mildly to moderately elevated.

treatments_and_meds.treatment_or_med: Empiric antiviral therapy for suspected zoster
treatments_and_meds.details: Given her history of V1 zoster with ophthalmic involvement and new right facial ulcerative lesions with increased pain and headache, she was started on systemic acyclovir (initially oral, then IV) and topical acyclovir ointment, along with acyclovir eye ointment per Ophthalmology. After Dermatology biopsies and virologic studies from skin scrapings and tissue were negative for HSV and VZV, and pathology favored eosinophilic hypersensitivity/folliculitis, acyclovir was discontinued in consultation with Infectious Disease and Dermatology.

Dermatology performed punch biopsies of the left arm and right face, which showed eosinophilic hypersensitivity reaction with follicular accentuation and negative HSV/VZV, PAS-D, and Gram stains. Tissue culture grew only coagulase-negative staph. Based on these findings, the rash was managed as eosinophilic dermatitis/folliculitis with hydroxyzine for pruritus and topical mupirocin cream 2% twice daily to facial lesions. Systemic cephalexin, initially considered for impetigo, was not continued. By discharge, facial ulcerations and chronic prurigo lesions were healing and pruritus was improved.

treatments_and_meds.treatment_or_med: Evaluation of headache with neuroimaging and lumbar puncture
treatments_and_meds.details: Because of worsening chronic headaches with photophobia in the setting of advanced HIV, she underwent CT head, MRI brain without contrast, and a fluoroscopic-guided lumbar puncture. CT and MRI showed no infarct, hemorrhage, mass, or abnormal parenchymal signal. LP yielded clear CSF with normal cell counts, protein, and glucose, negative cryptococcal antigen, and negative bacterial, fungal, viral, and AFB cultures. These results ruled out CNS infection or mass lesion, and headaches were managed symptomatically with oxycodone and later acetaminophen–caffeine–butalbital.

She continued thrice-weekly hemodialysis during the admission. Pre-dialysis labs showed elevated creatinine, BUN, phosphate, and intermittent hyperkalemia, which improved post-dialysis. She experienced transient intradialytic hypotension that responded to small saline boluses. Chronic ESRD medications were optimized: sevelamer carbonate dose was increased to 1600 mg TID with meals, cinacalcet 60 mg daily was continued, and she received IV doxercalciferol and epoetin with dialysis, along with heparin for circuit anticoagulation and heparin dwell for catheter locks.

treatments_and_meds.treatment_or_med: HIV antiretroviral therapy and opportunistic infection prophylaxis
treatments_and_meds.details: She had restarted HAART two weeks prior to admission with abacavir 600 mg daily, atazanavir 300 mg daily, ritonavir 100 mg daily, and emtricitabine 200 mg twice weekly; this regimen was continued throughout hospitalization. Given her advanced immunosuppression, she also received Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia prophylaxis with TMP-SMX DS one tablet three times weekly and MAC prophylaxis with azithromycin 1200 mg once weekly. CSF HIV-1 viral load was obtained as part of the LP workup. She was discharged on the same HAART and prophylaxis regimen with outpatient HIV follow-up.

treatments_and_meds.treatment_or_med: Pain control for post-herpetic neuralgia and headache
treatments_and_meds.details: Her chronic right facial and scalp pain from prior V1 zoster and her headaches were managed with neuropathic and opioid analgesics. She was maintained on desipramine 25 mg daily for neuropathic pain and received oxycodone immediate-release and later oxycodone–acetaminophen (5 mg/325 mg) as needed for moderate to severe pain. Acetaminophen alone and a combination of acetaminophen–caffeine–butalbital were also used for headache control. These measures led to moderate improvement in pain by discharge.

treatments_and_meds.treatment_or_med: Management of atrial fibrillation and stroke prophylaxis
treatments_and_meds.details: With a history of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, she experienced at least one brief episode of AF with rapid ventricular response during the hospitalization that self-terminated. She remained hemodynamically stable and largely asymptomatic. Short-term rate control with agents such as diltiazem and metoprolol was considered but not continued long term. Given her low stroke risk and concerns about bleeding and adherence, systemic anticoagulation was not started; instead, she was maintained on aspirin 325 mg daily for stroke prophylaxis.
